review_title: A lot of sad employees live here
job_title: Senior Staff Specialist in Rochester, NY
pros: I think the benefits are very good. Especially if you're interested in actually attending classes or school here. I hear the daycare is great and if you have children who will attend here, you'll save a boatload of money.
cons: I have never worked at a place where everyone is locked in their office and silent all day. I'm not a fan of forced socializing, but when it doesn't happen naturally that's because people are miserable. The pay is atrociously low. The people in charge have been here 20+ years sometimes. The amount of stagnant boomer energy is stifling. Onboarding for a new administrative employee is almost non-existent. And everything is made extremely complicated. I can't even begin to describe the nightmare that is the update for the new cloud based phone system. So much information is pushed out to us. It's beyond overwhelming. Hundreds of emails, thousands of Slack messages. Again, being head up by 50-60 years olds who just love to argue every single possible step along the way. It freaking terrible and I get a panic attack just thinking about it. Then there's the ticket system. If you are an employee and need literally anything, even to ask a question, you need to put a ticket in. Then some student worker making minimum wage who has zero problem solving skills is basically what you get. At least 60% of my job is wrangling tickets for my department that could be solved in moments but instead takes days, several emails and a wheelbarrow full of frustration.

review_title: Used To Be Better - They Truly Don't Care About Employees Anymore
pros:
- Generally good health benefits even in spite of their now 2 yr old change to plans with co-insurance as well as co-payments
- Above average contributions to retirement account
- For those that use them, tuition and/or tuition exchange benefits are very valuable
cons:
This is all from a staff perspective - faculty are platinum (apparently):
- Worse than average compensation esp. considering that we have not had a raise that matches the cost of living increase for well over ten years; therefore, employees are literally making less money every year they work here
- Lack of true management; RIT has a relatively flat management structure in a lot of departments, and with increasing workloads, managers can't manage; their time is spent doing an amalgamation of overflow tasks and responsibilities that can't be done by their current supervisees. (This is not true for Advancement where every other person is a Director or Associate Director and seems to have a plethora of people beneath them to assist them; the same goes for Finance & Administration where it seems any number of positions are readily and easily approved.)
- They do not try to retain staff talent at all; after a switch in HR leadership several years ago as well as changes at the Executive level, RIT does not counter if you receive a new offer elsewhere. This has resulted in the drainage of a lot of intrinsic knowledge and efficiencies from long term employees. 
- A significant amount of people have retired during the pandemic or directly after it, leaving a very large knowledge and experience gap. 
- Vacation time - between 5 and 20 years, exempt staff receive NO additional vacation time. That simply does not make sense - our lives change and evolve. We need more vacation time sooner to accommodate our lives esp. since you changed the sick time policy to supposedly coincide with NYS policies.
- Sick time went from unlimited to 12 days per year supposedly because of NYS guidance which makes little sense given that unlimited up to 5 days before having to on short term disability seems to be a much better deal than an accrual basis of 12 days per year.

pros:
RIT has an overall friendly work environment depending on the division, department and/or college that you work under.
 They offer adoption assistance and other non-traditional benefits.
cons:
- No real wage increases for over 10 years. RIT does not offer cost of living increases but rather "merit increases" (typically 1-2%) based on performance. Even performing above and beyond only equates to a small percentage more than others who are performing at par or below. 
 - Merit increases have been less than the cost of living increases (3%) for at least 10 years with many years offering no increases at all. With increasing health care costs , health care premiums (each year's increase is typically 7-8%), AND being told to save more for retirement as RIT changes retirement benefits, individuals - mostly staff as faculty are treated as gods - are effectively making less now than they did 10 years ago. Faculty are given increases from a separate pool of money and more often than not receive increases higher than staff despite already making decent wages.
 - HR and the administration changed their views of employee retention and compensation several years ago. Top performers are being recruited by outside sources with RIT not even attempting to retain them. We are "disposable and replaceable". They have chosen to ignore the intrinsic value of long term employees. It is evident in my interactions with many of the replacements that we have lost a lot of what makes RIT work.
 - Internal "promotions" are often met with a zero increase in pay because the individual is internal and already with in the wage band of the new position therefore taking on new responsibilities and stress without compensation.
- This year they sent out messaging hailing that they were not increasing health care premiums without pointing out the fact that they introduced co-insurance for a number of procedures such as X-rays, MRIs, surgeries, etc. as well as a deductible. The HR response was that many individuals do not utilize those things so the people that do need get those procedures need to pay more. In effect, the sick get poorer and those that are healthy are "ok". Isn't the whole point of health insurance to cover a spectrum of risk factors and costs for the broad spectrum of the people under it. For example, someone that needs a gall bladder surgery - last year they would have paid roughly $300 in co-pays for the Dr. and Surgical Center. That same surgery after Jan 1, 2021 now costs that same individual more than $3,000.
 - RIT is constantly looking for space yet staff that are not front facing are being made to return to campus post-pandemic. For what? Staff that have proven their efficiency (often better than in office) should be allowed to stay remote. Faculty wanting to be able to drop in is not a valid reason to make a staff member return to campus. Email and zoom are effective for today's workplace needs for non-student facing employees or faculty support.
 - People say that the educational benefits and non-traditional employments make up for some of the issues, but I have no dependents and I am not planning to adopt. So...???

review_title: Great people, great environment - a good & fun place to wrok
pros: RIT is a university that is constantly striving for high quality education beyond the classroom. Thus, there are plenty of opportunities for people who see a university as not just a workplace but as a place where they can contribute to help educate people and help shape the future of its students. Plus, there is always a possibility to continue learning not only while at work but also after work.  I think the benefit package is quite good and since RIT is determined to grow and keep up with the best universities in the country I am sure there will always be interesting job opportunities.
cons: Despite all the good things and the good benefits package that comes with being employed at RIT I think the payment level as such could be higher. That is true at least for Non-Faculty. I cannot say much about Faculty, but administrative staff could be payed more competitively. Other than that there is nothing else that one should considerate when starting at RIT. Oh ya, at lot of people complain about weather, too long winter and too much rain but that is more Rochester specific than employer specific. Again, I can only recommend RIT as a potential employer.

review_title: My dedication, work ethic and devotion to excellence were mostly wasted there, as politics trump everything.
pros: The greatest environment, tremendous benefits, and the blessing of being amidst bright, ambitious students. The campus is a wonderful place to spend one's workdays.
cons: The hypocrisy of many who manage the place. Legal limitations and biases have led to unfair work practices (i.e. Affirmative Action policies and DOUBLE STANDARDS which reward minorities, regardless of their acumen or ethics). Innocent, honest workers sometimes are the victims of reverse discrimination.

pros: Great working environment and a wealth of resources for professional development. Good benefits for full time employees. Very neutral management structure and fair compensation.
cons: Some of the management becomes too powerful with no way to challenge them, employees form a niche requirement for their skills, tenured professors can lose motivation to perform at their fullest. Getting funding and hiring new people is always difficult.

job_title: Desktop Support Technician in Rochester, NY
pros: The position has on the job training that works to supplement the learning that you have done in and out of the classroom.  As far as being employed as a student you do not enjoy the benefits that full time employees do such as vacation time or other benefits, however you can be flexible in scheduling you hours and the team is fun to work with.
cons: The chain of command gets annoying. While your immediate superiors are usually very pleasant to work with, it seems hard to get extra resources when looking to your department for those resources.

review_title: Pays you to take your classes
pros: Loved being able to get paid for doing what I had to do anyway: go to my classes and be attentive. Being a notetaker actually helped me focus better and made me more accountable to myself. Make sure you take notes on your laptop if you can, otherwise you may not get to keep your notes at the end of the semester.
cons: The pay isn't worth it if you're looking for something to significantly supplement your income, but it's easy money (get paid to go to class). You don't get to clock in if there's an exam and you aren't guaranteed to have a notetaking job each semester.

review_title: Good school, enlightened leaders, fair compensation
job_title: Senior Staff Engineer in Rochester, NY
pros: In general, employees treated well.  President and top level management seem competent and fair.  Benefits above average for staff, no compelling reason to unionize.  Focus on preparing students for work, rather than research.  Lots of internship opportunities.  Very techie / multi-cultural / excited students / events
cons: Lower level management sometimes lacking management skills and not well monitored - may be many years behind in "annual" reviews without apparent repercussions.  Lots of older equipment that never dies.  Training budgets lacking - at least in some dept / institutes.

pros: RIT has great benefits to take advantage of! Free tuition for employees, 403B matching and Excellent healthcare. They also encourage personal growth through quick classes that can be taken at any time.
cons: Professional growth at RIT is slow mainly because of high competition. Hourly Pay/Salaries are low compared to other companies and since people tend to stay in the same position for years and year, they tend to become stagnant and not very innovative.

pros: Love being able to work out at lunch time.  Enjoy the discounted exercise classes.  Can take undergraduate classes for free.  Free tuition for my children after 5 years
cons: Not working with cutting edge technology in my position.  The salary could be higher.  I share an office, there is not enough space in my area for everyone to have their own office.

review_title: Lively work atmosphere thats always improving
pros: Work is hardly ever boring, and its a very active atmosphere. The university is constantly pushing for being more environmentally friendly and low-impact.
cons: At times it can be exceedingly crazy depending on the time of year. At other times the work is very slow moving, but thats not necessarily a bad thing.

review_title: The office is the first choice partner for decision support, analytics and institutional intelligence.
job_title: Dashboard Developer/Data Analyst in Rochester, NY
pros: From Storytelling to using parameters, I think I have significantly enhanced my dashboard development skills as I compare to my latest dashboards to the previous ones. So far I was just reading about management and processes, but at the office of IR I got an opportunity to apply it. In my opinion that is the game changer as you never get stuck for a long time, which is a drawback in several other models.
cons: I did not face anything negative per say. Just that the work could get more interesting.

review_title: Fun, productive student employment opportunity that provides pre-career experience
job_title: Marketing Team Member in Rochester, NY
pros: The company environment and personality is very friendly and diverse. Working at CAB leads to experiences and opportunities that are unique to the organization. We get to work during fun events and meet big name acts as well. The office itself is very open and that allows for a lot of collaboration and input from all areas.
cons: Its easy to get so sucked into the culture that you find yourself over-extending to make ends meet occasionally. The fun aspects of the job are sometimes balanced by some more stressful decision making and difficult situations.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros: RIT gives you the opportunity to do what you want. You need to look for opportunities and take any that are given to you. If you don't do this, you will not enjoy it here.
cons: Social life is kind of poor. Social opportunities are hard to find but they are there! If you join an organization you are passionate about you will be just fine.

review_title: RIT, a great place to get stuck going nowhere
pros: RIT is a great place for people who aren't looking to rise up or excel. It's a very slow paced business with opportunity to work with cool things and enjoying the benefits.
cons: RIT is a place where you can go nowhere fast. Many coworkers are RIT alumni who never seemed to quite make the transition to the working world. Not a ton of ambition for those who choose to stay in academia.

review_title: So much depends upon where you are
pros: Rich learning environment, opportunity to interact with and learn from students, and colleagues. I have a fantastic manager who is sensitive to my needs and allows me to follow my passions.
cons: Not all managers are like my own. There is a push for more publications and research and less emphasis on pragmatic work experience. The institution is in flux.

review_title: I worked as an assistant in the student services office in my college.
job_title: Student Office Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros: The staff assistants and advisors were extremely friendly and helpful. I made the effort to get to know them and that made the whole experience more enjoyable (started getting freebies, free food, and good advice).
cons: I worked in the office over the summer so it was pretty slow. Some days I would have zero work and others I would be extremely busy. I was also the only assistant over the summer when there are usually two working at a time so it made it more challenging.

pros: Lab time can be good to do homework and get paid.
cons: If a teacher isn't doing there job well you'll know quickly. Students will either not do there work and hope you finish it for them, or a teacher has screwed up a lecture and now you have 6 people asking you the same question from the same class. Work can be draining if you do more than 5 hours.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in San Jose, CA
pros: The students are payed per semester and so the pay turns out to be great in terms of hours. Also the work hours are flexible and your are allowed to work in and out as per your convenience provided the work is done.
cons: The opportunities to get a job as a research assistant are quite few here and only the lucky few get those.

pros: It was a fun place to work, fast paced and never the same thing every time. Free food. Sign up for your own shifts.
cons: Lots of standing. Sometimes there was drama between supervisors. Getting home can be difficult if you can't park on campus and have a late shift.

pros: Great place to work, good infrastructure and some really cool research in Graphics, Computer Vision, Algorithms, Robotics, Big Data etc. Students are really good esp. Undergraduates.
cons:
Pay for adjuncts could be more considering the work load. Added new benefits to adjuncts effective Jan 1st 2016. 
RIT is heading towards being a research institute, so would like to see more motivation for students to get involved in research than being Co-Op or Industry oriented.

pros:
- good salary with respect to the job market
- lots of support tools and resources for teaching
- ok medical benefits
cons:
- ideology of students as "clients" and professors as "customer service providers" seriously affect the stand and respect for faculty
- few minority faculty make it throught he system; hiring numbers are up but tenure and retention are low
-intense quarter system,...plus some times different course sections (with different course number) are assigned to the same classroom, so the faculty ends up teaching more sections than originally planned

pros: Great benefits, good salaries, training provided, great co-workers, beautiful campus, lots of events available to staff to attend, flexible schedules when appropriate, lots of volunteer opportunities.
cons: Salaries are much lower that corporate salaries, but higher than most of the other local universities in the Rochester, NY area. Some supervisors are not skilled managers, they have just been on campus forever and were promoted years ago.

review_title: Graduate Assistant - Great opportunity for students
pros:
- decent compensation for the work you do
- beautiful campus
- can somewhat set your own hours
- allows you to help others learn and learn more yourself
cons: There are significant cons that I can think of. You can only work a max of 20 hrs per week, but with all the work you have to do for your classes, that isn't really a bad thing.

pros: The most value adding advantage of this job is that it gives the MBA students the chance to be involved in real consulting projects with real businesses located in Rochester metropolitan area.
cons: The type of companies' that look for the consulting projects are small sized entities that are taking advantage of the low fees. On the other hand, start ups and small entities require more effort that adds up to the learning experience.

pros: Great place to work at. Nice environment and great diversity with both deaf and hearing students. You have plenty of time to finish your work. Nice co-workers and great team players. Always there to help you and guide you. IT is a great place to work.
cons: The pay was not the best but manageable. I did not have a chance to receive any benefits due to not being full time employee, but I heard the other employees and the benefits were very good.

review_title: Amazing job, great students, good pay!
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Rochester, NY
pros:
1. The staff is helpful when you start as a new GTA.
2. The students are amazing and brilliant!
3. The pay is good to sustain a student life
cons: None really. This job is just great! You are never over burdened with this work, and you can always focus on your grad school classes.

review_title: Great individual departments, but silos of dysfunctional leadership.
pros: The people you work with in the various departments at RIT are great, working with students is exceptionally rewarding and they really do value student interaction with full-time and part-time staff/faculty.
cons: Top-level leadership is disconnected with students, faculty and staff issues and make decisions that are not always in the best interest for strategic positioning of the institute or departments within

pros: Smart students. A culture of innovation. Students have ambition. Teachers are inspiring. A world class technology and design school in Rochester NY. I enjoyed teaching here and would recommend it to any adjunct professor.
cons: Low pay for adjuncts. Especially low for a 10 week class that meets twice a week. The campus is very dated and feels surprisingly dull for a cool technology and design school.

pros: RIT has the resources to hire graduate students. The hourly work generally helps make ends meet.
cons: A lot of red tape and forms. Be careful if you're extremely dependent on the hourly salary—RIT usually forgets to "rehire" or shuffle paperwork around the beginning and end of semesters, which means you may lose a week or two of income just because you don't have a number, or a form, or a barcode, or some other administrative puzzle piece.

job_title: Student Manager of Photography Cage in Rochester, NY
pros: I was able to play with high quality photographic equipment while making money and making lifetime connections to fellow students. With the switch to the semester system, the working hours became more flexible around everyone's schedules. I believe the SPAS Photography Cage was the best choice of work for me as a photo student.
cons: Minimum wage for every employee other than student managers, and even with student manager positions they didn't pay a lot.

review_title: Had a great experience building up an initiative from scratch.
pros: Great benefits, pleasant setting, but mostly wonderful people full of creativity and innovative thoughts in an expansive atmosphere of expansion and growth.
cons: Overall, stretching themselves too thin, trying to do too much with too few resources and not enough creativity and innovation in the administrative sector.

review_title: An organization that is growing and which values excellence in work!
job_title: Human Resources Representative in Rochester, NY
pros: Nice location for family; close to lakes and beautiful parks, not congested with traffic, good schools and universities and a community that welcomes involvement.
cons: Growth also has a downside in that more work seems to be required to keep pace with expecations.

pros: Very down to earth people. Many are concerned with improving academia and producing good value for current and future students.
cons: Can get disorganized a bit. Unless you know the right people, your voice might be lost into the ether. Stable working environment where you can make a decent college-level hourly pay and still finish all your classwork.

job_title: ITS Helpdesk Representative in Rochester, NY
pros: The Service Desk is a great place to work, with great people and a good atmosphere. Occasionally, there is little work to do and it is enjoyable to talk with the other employees.
cons: There are times (Especially right after a break) when the queue will be flooded and there are non-stop calls. It is times like these when it can be difficult to keep track of the tasks at hand and multitasking becomes a challenge.

review_title: Developing People Skills at a Tech Oriented University

pros: Professional experience. Loved working with students and faculty on a regular basis. RIT is also a very green campus which is really nice.

review_title: Great place to work, limited upward mobility.

review_title: Great place to work and study

pros: You learn a lot, make a bit of money, and definitely utilize your people skills. A great experience.

pros: RIT is growing rapidly and so presents opportunities. The town isn't neither too big nor too small so there is scope for a reasonable work life balance.
